description: From Middle English wrecched (“(adjective) characterized by or suffering hardship or misfortune, miserable, unfortunate, unhappy; indigent, poor; of low economic or social status, lowly; (noun) miserable person”) [and other forms], from wrecche (“characterized by or suffering hardship or misfortune, miserable, unfortunate, unhappy; indigent, poor; of low economic or social status, lowly; base, contemptible, vile; reprehensible, wicked; miserly, stingy; of little importance, paltry, worthless”) (from Late Old English wrecc, from Old English wreċċa (“an exile, outcast”), ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *wreg- (“to follow, track; to hunt”)) + -ed (suffix forming adjectives). The English word is analysable as wretch (“(obsolete) wretched”, adjective) +‎ -ed (suffix forming adjectives).

adjectives.description: wretched (comparative wretcheder or more wretched, superlative wretchedest or most wretched)

entries.meaning: Characterized by or feeling deep affliction or distress; very miserable.
examples: Synonyms: dejected, (archaic or obsolete) wretchful; see also Thesaurus:lamentable, Thesaurus:sad
I felt wretched after my wife died.

entries.meaning: Of an inferior or unworthy nature or social status; contemptible, lowly.
examples: The street was full of wretched beggars dressed in rags.

entries.meaning: Of an insignificant, mean, or poor nature; miserable, paltry, worthless.
Of a person, etc.: behaving in a manner deserving contempt; base, despicable, wicked.
Of weather: causing much discomfort; very unpleasant; miserable.
(informal) Used to express annoyance towards or dislike of someone or something: bloody, damned.
examples: Will you please stop playing that wretched trombone!
